section.title: Finding an exponential function given two points

outcomes.outcome: You will be able to find a formula for an exponential curve that connects two points in the plane.
You will be able to predict the population of the United States and other countries in the year 2050.
You will be able to model the amount of \mathrm{CO}_2 emitted in the United States over time.

section.author: Jordan
section.p: Consider a puzzle where two points are given on the plane, and you are asked to connect them with a curve. There are infinitely many ways to do this. In the past, you've connected two points with a straight line (as in ) and found the equation that represents that line. Of course, you could also connect the points with a random curve of your liking (as in ). In this section we will try to connect the points with an exponential curve (as in ) and simultaneously find that curve's equation.

section.p: In many application problems we will encounter situations where we wish to find an exponential function that goes through the two points (x_1,y_1) and (x_2,y_2). Let's practice this skill before moving on to the applied problems.

example.author: Hughes
example.statement: Find an exponential function f given by f(t)=a\,b^t whose graph goes through the points \left(-2,\frac{3}{4}\right) and (2,12) as shown in .

solution.p:
We will need to find a and b in the equation f(t)=a\,b^t. We begin by using the given ordered pairs to write a system of equations
\sfrac{3}{4} & = a\,b^{-2} 12 & = a\,b^2
We can eliminate a by equating the quotients formed by the two sides of the equations. One result is
\frac{12}{\sfrac{3}{4}} = \frac{a\,b^{2}}{a\,b^{-2}}\qquad \Longrightarrow\qquad 16 = b^4

This implies that either b=2 or b=-2. Since the base of an exponential function must be positive (b>0), we can conclude that b=2. Substituting this into one of the original equations, we find that
12 = a\,(2)^2 \qquad \Longrightarrow\qquad a = 3
Note that we can substitute the value of b into either of the original equations.
We conclude that f(t)=3\cdot 2^t, which is graphed in . The number 2 is called the growth factor; every time t increases by 1, the value of f(t) grows by a factor of 2.

exercisegroup.statement: Find an exponential function f of the form f(t)=a\,b^t whose graph goes through the ordered pairs (1,8) and (3,128). Identify the growth factor.

section.p: When dealing with application problems the values of a and b will rarely evaluate to integers. The method for finding an exponential model remains the same though.

section.author: Jordan
section.p: Suppose that we have some reason to model a situation using an exponential function. In real-world applications, we might only have two points of data to work with. If we treat these data points as two points on a plane, we can use the skills we have been practicing to explicitly give the exponential model that we would like to use.

example.statement: An outbreak of avian flu occurs in a crowded city. Doctors immediately identify 25 patients who are infected. One week later, there are 2391 people infected. If we assume that the number of infected patients can be modeled with exponential growth, what is the rule for the exponential model?

solution.p: We choose to model this situation by treating the given data as points on a plane. Initially (or when t=0) there are 25 patients, so (0,25) is one point. At time 7 (measured in days) there are 2391 patients, so (7,2391) is the other point. These points are sketched in .

example.p: Once we have this model we can answer interesting questions with it. For example, how many people will be infected 3 days after the initial outbreak?

solution.p:
Since
f(3) & = 25\left(\frac{2391}{25}\right)^{\sfrac{3}7} & \approx 177
we can say that there will be about 177 infected people 3 days after the initial outbreak.

example.p: We can also look at a graph of the model (as in ) and answer other interesting questions. For example, when will the number of infected persons reach 20,000?

solution.p: The graph suggests that around the tenth day after the initial outbreak, there will be 20000 infected persons.

statement.p: Many buildings in Detroit have been vacant and unattended for several years. Suppose that the amount of wood (in ) that remains attached to a building t years after it has been abandoned is an exponential function of time. A particular building was abandoned on July 3, 1999. On July 3, 2002 there were 53 cubic yards of wood attached to the building and on July 3, 2009 there were 47 cubic yards of wood attached to the building.

Find a function w, given by w(t)=a\, b^t, that outputs the volume of remaining wood on the structure t years after July 3, 1999. Round the value of a to the nearest tenth and the value of b to the nearest thousandth.

solution.p:
We are given that w(3)=53 and w(10)=37 so
a\,b^3 & = 53 a\,b^{10} & =47
Eliminating for b gives b^7=\frac{47}{53} and therefore
b & = \sqrt[7]{\frac{47}{53}} & \approx 0.983
Using this value of b in gives
a & = \frac{53}{\left( \frac{47}{53} \right)^{\sfrac{3}{7}}} & \approx 55.8
We conclude that
w(t) \approx 55.8(0.983)^t

exercisegroup.author: Kouzes
exercisegroup.title: US population
exercisegroup.statement: The population of the United States has increased roughly exponentially from 76.2 million people in 1900 to 309 million people in 2010.

exercise.statement: Find a formula that approximates the number of people in the U.S.A., p(t), in millions, t years after 1900 assuming that the population grows exponentially.
Use your model to approximate the population of the U.S.A. in the year 2000.

solution.p: p(100)\approx 272.072992; the population of the U.S.A. in the year 2000 was approximately 272 million people, according to the model.

exercise.statement: The actual population of the U.S.A. in 2000 was about 282 million people. Did your approximation from underestimate or overestimate, and by how much?

solution.p: The model underestimated the actual population by about 10 million people.

exercise.statement: Use the actual populations of the U.S.A. in the years 2000 and 2010 to find a formula that approximates the number of people in the U.S.A., P(t), in millions, t years after 2000 assuming that the population grows exponentially.

The population of the U.S.A. was 151 million people in 1950 . How close of an approximation does your model from give? How close of an approximation does your model from give? Why are both models off? Which model is better for making a prediction about 1950?

solution.p: P(-50) \approx 178.526320 and p(50)\approx 143.985979. P(-50) was an overestimate by about 27.5 million people, or 18.2. p(50) was an underestimate by about 7 million people, or 4.6. So the prediction based off of the model that used the years 1900 and 2000 is better. Generally, it is better to interpolate than to extrapolate.

exercisegroup.title: Greenhouse gases
exercisegroup.statement: As our cars, homes, businesses and industry become more efficient, each person is responsible for the production of less carbon dioxide (CO_{2}) a greenhouse gas. The US Energy Information Administration provides the estimates for future quantities of CO_{2} that each person will produce. They know that in 2010, on average each US citizen was responsible for the production of 18.1 metric tons of CO_{2}, and they predict that in 2031 the average US citizen will be responsible for 16.3 metric tons of CO_{2}.

exercise.statement: Find a formula for c(t), an approximation for the average amount of CO_{2} each US citizen will be responsible for emitting, in metric tons, t years after the year 2010 assuming that the amount of CO_{2} produced decays exponentially.
Use your model to approximate the average amount of CO_2 each US citizen was responsible for in the year 2000.

solution.p: c(-10)\approx 19.025713. Each US citizen was responsible for approximately 19.03 tons of CO_2 in 2000.

exercise.statement: If you have an answer to , use it to find a formula for C(t), an approximation for the total amount of CO_{2} that all citizens of the U.S.A. will be responsible for emitting, in millions of metric tons, t years after the year 2000.

statement.p: Tapfish is a free mobile device app where you set up a digital aquarium. We can use the application to create approximations of exponential functions. We have simplified the nature of the application to make this problem easier. The app allows you to buy and sell fish once per day. The fish grow in size (and therefore value) after owning them for just one day. Our goal is to maximize the number of fish in our aquarium over a period of 9 days.

exercise.statement: Let F(t) be the number of fish we have in our aquarium on day t. Complete the F(t) column in . Assume that we always buy and sell the maximum number of fish, that we use whatever leftover coins we have from previous transactions, and that we cannot buy fractions of fish.
Make a graph of y=F(t) using the points in your table.

statement.p: The function F represents the exact number of fish that we have on a given day. We are going to find an approximate formula for F using an exponential function. To be clear, we will use A to represent the function that approximates F.

Pick any two of the points from and find a function of the form, A(t)=a\,b^t, that approximates the number of fish in the tank t days after starting. (Answers will vary depending on which two points you use.)

exercise.statement: Complete the A(t) column in using 6 decimal places, and compare the values of A(t) to the values of F(t).

exercise.statement: Let S(t) represent the Solar PV Power Capacity (in ) at time t in years since 2000. Use the first and last data points in to write down two ordered pairs that lie on the graph of S.
Use your ordered pairs to find a formula for S in the form S(t)=a\,b^t. State b to three decimal places.
What are the growth rate and growth factor for your function S?

solution.p: The growth factor is \left( \frac{8325}{877} \right)^{\sfrac{1}{7}}\approx 1.379. The growth rate is \left( \frac{8325}{877} \right)^{\sfrac{1}{7}}-1 \approx 0.379, or about 37.9 per year.

exercise.statement: According to the article, the data implies a compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of 37.9. Is your model consistent with this statement?

solution.p: Yes; we found b\approx 1.379, which means the annual growth rate is approximately 37.9.

exercise.statement: According to your model, what is the Solar PV Power Capacity in 2010? Compare this with the actual value of 13729, and give reasons for the difference.

solution.p: S(10)\approx 21840.54. This is much larger than 13729, which indicates that the growth rate did not continue at 37.9 after 2007.
